The retelling activity is powerful: children often discover they are better at remembering and telling stories than they expected. For the folktale, you might choose an Anansi story (West African), a pourquoi tale (why stories), or a myth your family connects with culturally. The act of performing for an audience — making eye contact, using gestures, varying tone — builds confidence and communication skills that extend far beyond this lesson.

title: Read-Aloud: 'The Evolution of Calpurnia Tate' — Chapters 7-9
description: Continue reading the novel, focusing on Calpurnia's deepening scientific investigations and the growing tension between her intellectual pursuits and her family's expectations. Students analyze theme development and practice making text-to-self and text-to-world connections.
instructions:
1. Review chapters 4-6: What has Calpurnia learned? How is her relationship with her grandfather developing?
2. Read chapters 7-9 aloud.
3. Discuss emerging themes: curiosity vs. conformity, the role of mentors, change and growth.
4. Make connections: text-to-self (How does this relate to my life?), text-to-world (How does this relate to our history/science studies?).
5. Analyze a key passage closely: What is the author doing with word choice and imagery?
6. Journal: Write about a mentor in your life.
materials_needed: The Evolution of Calpurnia Tate by Jacqueline Kelly

slides.heading: The Evolution of Calpurnia Tate
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey! This first slide is just letting us know what we're diving into today. We're going to keep reading "The Evolution of Calpurnia Tate," specifically chapters 7 through 9. We'll be thinking about the big ideas, or themes, in the story and how they connect to our own lives and the world around us.

slides.text: Before reading, review: What scientific observations has Calpurnia been making? How is her grandfather guiding her? What conflicts has she experienced between her interests and her family's expectations? Make a prediction: What do you think will happen next?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, before we jump into the new chapters, this slide is like a quick warm-up. It wants us to think back to what we've already read about Calpurnia. What cool science stuff has she figured out? How is her grandpa helping her learn? And has anyone been making it tough for her to follow her interests? After that, take a guess about what might happen next!

slides.text: As we read chapters 7-9, we will practice three types of connections: Text-to-Self — 'This reminds me of when I...' Text-to-Text — 'This is similar to another book/story where...' Text-to-World — 'This connects to what we have been learning about...' Strong readers make connections constantly — it is how we make meaning from what we read.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about how readers become super smart by making connections. It's showing us three ways to do that: Text-to-Self, which is when something in the book reminds you of your own life; Text-to-Text, like when a story reminds you of another book; and Text-to-World, where you link what you're reading to things we've learned in science or history.

slides.text: Read chapters 7-9, pausing at key moments to discuss and make connections. Pay special attention to: How does the author use nature descriptions to reflect Calpurnia's inner world? What do we learn about Calpurnia's mother and her values? How does the 1899 setting shape the story differently than if it were set today?
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's time to read chapters 7 through 9! As we read, try to notice how the author describes nature – does it tell us something about how Calpurnia is feeling? Also, pay attention to her mom and what's important to her. And think about how different things might be for Calpurnia because she lives way back in 1899, not today.

slides.prompt: After reading, choose one: (1) Text-to-World Connection: Write a paragraph connecting something in these chapters to our study of genetics, evolution, or human history. How does what Calpurnia is learning relate to what we have been studying? (2) Mentor Reflection: Calpurnia's grandfather is her mentor. Write about a mentor in your life — someone who has helped you see the world differently. How did they teach you? What have you learned from them? (3) Close Reading: Choose one paragraph from today's reading that you found powerful. Copy it in your journal and write an analysis: What is the author doing with word choice, imagery, or sentence structure? Why is this passage effective?
slides.mascot_explanation: After we finish reading, you get to choose one of these cool activities. You can write about how something in the book connects to our science lessons, like genetics, or write about a person in your life who taught you a lot, like Calpurnia's grandfather. Or, you can pick a sentence you really liked and explain why the author's words make it so powerful. You've got 20 minutes to pick one and get started!

slides.text: The best books change how we see the world. Calpurnia's story is not just about science in 1899 — it is about the courage to be curious, the power of mentorship, and the tension between being who you are and being who others expect you to be. These are timeless themes that connect to every reader's life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student make meaningful text-to-self and text-to-world connections? Can they identify and discuss emerging themes in the novel?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is reminding us why reading this book is so awesome. It's not just a story about a girl in the past; it's about being brave enough to be curious, the importance of people who guide us, and figuring out how to be yourself even when others have different ideas for you. These big ideas are things everyone thinks about, no matter when they live.

parent_notes: Making connections (text-to-self, text-to-text, text-to-world) is a key reading comprehension strategy that good readers do automatically. Modeling this for your child is powerful: as you read aloud, pause and share your own connections ('This reminds me of...' or 'This connects to what we learned about...'). The close reading option is excellent for developing analytical skills — choosing a single paragraph and examining the author's craft teaches students to read like writers. The mentor reflection is personally meaningful and helps children articulate gratitude and awareness of influential relationships in their lives. Adjust reading pace to your child's interest — if they are deeply engaged, read more; if attention is waning, read less and discuss more.
